verses.verse: Like snow<WH7950> in summer,<WH7019> and as rain<WH4306> in harvest,<WH7105> so honor<WH3519> is not fitting<WH5000> for a fool.<WH3684>
Like a fluttering<WH5110> sparrow,<WH6833> like a darting<WH5774> swallow,<WH1866> so the undeserved curse<WH7045> doesn't<WH935> come to rest.<WH935>
A whip<WH7752> is for the horse,<WH5483> a bridle<WH4964> for the donkey,<WH2543> and a rod<WH7626> for the back<WH1460> of fools!<WH3684>
Don't<WH6030> answer a fool<WH3684> according to his folly,<WH200> lest you also be like him.<WH7737>
Answer<WH6030> a fool<WH3684> according to his folly,<WH200> lest he be wise<WH2450> in his own eyes.<WH5869>
One who sends<WH7971> a message<WH1697> by the hand<WH3027> of a fool<WH3684> is cutting off<WH7096> feet<WH7272> and drinking<WH8354> violence.<WH2555>
Like the legs<WH7785> of the lame<WH6455> that hang loose:<WH1809> so is a parable<WH4912> in the mouth<WH6310> of fools.<WH3684>
As one who binds<WH6872> a stone<WH68> in a sling,<WH4773> so is he who gives<WH5414> honor<WH3519> to a fool.<WH3684>
Like a thornbush<WH2336> that goes<WH5927> into the hand<WH3027> of a drunkard,<WH7910> so is a parable<WH4912> in the mouth<WH6310> of fools.<WH3684>
As an archer<WH7227> who wounds<WH2342> all,<WH7936> so is he who hires a fool<WH3684> or he who hires<WH7936> those who pass by.<WH5674>
As a dog<WH3611> that returns<WH7725> to his vomit,<WH6892> so is a fool<WH3684> who repeats<WH8138> his folly.<WH200>
Do you see<WH7200> a man<WH376> wise<WH2450> in his own eyes?<WH5869> There is more hope<WH8615> for a fool than for him.<WH3684>
The sluggard<WH6102> says,<WH559> "There is a lion<WH7826> in the road!<WH1870> A fierce lion<WH7826> roams the streets!<WH7339>"
As the door<WH1817> turns<WH5437> on its hinges,<WH6735> so does the sluggard<WH6102> on his bed.<WH4296>
The sluggard<WH6102> buries<WH2934> his hand<WH3027> in the dish.<WH6747> He is too lazy<WH3811> to bring it back<WH7725> to his mouth.<WH6310>
The sluggard<WH6102> is wiser<WH2450> in his own eyes<WH5869> than seven men<WH7651> who answer<WH7725> with discretion.<WH2940>
Like one who grabs<WH2388> a dog<WH3611>'s ears<WH241> is one who passes by<WH5674> and meddles<WH5674> in a quarrel not his own.<WH7379>
Like a madman<WH3856> who shoots<WH3384> torches,<WH2131> arrows,<WH2671> and death,<WH4194>
is the man<WH376> who deceives<WH7411> his neighbor<WH7453> and says,<WH559> "Am I not joking?<WH7832>"
For lack<WH657> of wood<WH6086> a fire<WH784> goes out.<WH3518> Without gossip,<WH5372> a quarrel<WH4066> dies down.<WH8367>
As coals<WH6352> are to hot embers,<WH1513> and wood<WH6086> to fire,<WH784> so is a contentious<WH4079> man<WH376> to kindling<WH2787> strife.<WH7379>
The words<WH1697> of a whisperer<WH5372> are as dainty morsels,<WH3859> they go down<WH3381> into the innermost<WH990> parts.<WH2315>
Like silver<WH3701> dross<WH5509> on<WH6823> an earthen<WH2789> vessel are the lips<WH8193> of a fervent<WH1814> one with an evil<WH7451> heart.<WH3820>
A malicious<WH8130> man disguises<WH5234> himself with his lips,<WH8193> but he harbors<WH7896> evil<WH4820> in his heart.<WH7130>
When his speech<WH6963> is charming,<WH2603> don't<WH539> believe him;<WH7651> for there are seven abominations<WH8441> in his heart.<WH3820>
His malice<WH8135> may be concealed<WH3680> by deception,<WH4860> but his wickedness<WH7451> will be exposed<WH1540> in the assembly.<WH6951>
Whoever digs<WH3738> a pit<WH7845> shall fall<WH5307> into it.<WH1556> Whoever rolls a stone,<WH68> it will come back on him.<WH7725>
A lying<WH8267> tongue<WH3956> hates<WH8130> those it hurts;<WH1790> and a flattering<WH2509> mouth<WH6310> works<WH6213> ruin.<WH4072>
